claim: Most grand masters know what the French Defense is.

supporting.text: The French Defense is a well-known and classical chess opening, taught in most chess textbooks and studied by players at all levels, including grandmasters.

attacks.text: The French Defense is a well-known and classical chess opening, taught in most chess textbooks and studied by players at all levels, including grandmasters.
While the French Defense is well-known, not all grandmasters specialize in or regularly play classical openings, preferring hypermodern or unconventional systems.
Most grandmasters are familiar with classical openings like the French Defense due to their foundational role in chess education, even if they don't play them frequently.
Chess textbooks vary in coverage, and some may prioritize other openings over the French Defense, leading to gaps in knowledge among grandmasters from certain training backgrounds.
The French Defense is universally included in core chess curricula, making it unlikely for any grandmaster to be entirely unfamiliar with it.

supporting.text: Grandmasters are required to have deep knowledge of various openings, including the French Defense, as part of their professional training and preparation.

attacks.text: Grandmasters are required to have deep knowledge of various openings, including the French Defense, as part of their professional training and preparation.
Not all grandmasters specialize in classical openings like the French Defense; some focus on hypermodern or unconventional openings.
Even grandmasters who focus on unconventional openings still study classical openings like the French Defense to understand potential opponent strategies.
The French Defense is less popular in modern high-level play, reducing the necessity for grandmasters to study it deeply.
Despite its reduced popularity, the French Defense remains part of standard chess education and is still encountered in professional play.

supporting.text: The French Defense has been played in numerous high-level tournaments and matches, making it a standard part of a grandmaster's repertoire.

attacks.text: The French Defense has been played in numerous high-level tournaments and matches, making it a standard part of a grandmaster's repertoire.
Not all grandmasters specialize in classical openings like the French Defense; some focus on hypermodern or unorthodox systems.
The French Defense is a fundamental opening taught early in chess education, so even non-specialists are likely familiar with it.
The frequency of the French Defense in high-level play has declined in recent years, reducing its relevance to contemporary grandmasters.
Despite its declining frequency, the French Defense remains a staple in opening theory and is still studied for its strategic depth.

supporting.text: Chess databases and analysis tools frequently include the French Defense, ensuring that grandmasters are familiar with its key ideas and variations.

attacks.text: Chess databases and analysis tools frequently include the French Defense, ensuring that grandmasters are familiar with its key ideas and variations.
Not all grandmasters actively use chess databases or analysis tools, especially older or less tech-savvy players.
Even without databases, the French Defense is a fundamental opening taught early in chess education, so grandmasters would still know it.
Some grandmasters specialize in niche openings and may neglect studying mainstream ones like the French Defense.
Specialization in niche openings is rare among grandmasters, as they typically maintain broad opening knowledge for competitive flexibility.

supporting.text: The French Defense is part of the FIDE curriculum for advanced players, and grandmasters, being the highest-rated players, are expected to know it.

attacks.text: The French Defense is part of the FIDE curriculum for advanced players, and grandmasters, being the highest-rated players, are expected to know it.
Not all grandmasters specialize in openings like the French Defense; some may focus on other openings or aspects of the game.
The FIDE curriculum is standardized, so even grandmasters with different specializations would have studied the French Defense at some point.
Some grandmasters may have achieved their title decades ago and might not be up-to-date with current FIDE curriculum requirements.
Grandmasters are required to maintain a high level of play, which includes staying familiar with standard openings like the French Defense.

supporting.text: Many grandmasters have written books or articles on the French Defense, indicating their familiarity and expertise with the opening.

attacks.text: Many grandmasters have written books or articles on the French Defense, indicating their familiarity and expertise with the opening.
Writing about an opening does not necessarily mean deep practical knowledge or frequent use in games.
Grandmasters often analyze openings they don't personally use to understand opponents' strategies.
Some grandmasters may specialize in other openings and have limited experience with the French Defense.
Specialization doesn't preclude basic knowledge, as all grandmasters study a wide range of openings.
